overview:
## Overview

A *histogram* measures the number of times a data point for a variable falls into a specific range of possible values within a set of data. Usually, histograms are depicted as bar charts, in which each bar represents a range of values, and the height of each bar represents the number of times the value of the variable falls within a particular range. In this class, each bar is represented by a *bucket*.

A bucket holds the results for a series of measured values, such as all the events occurring between 3 and 5 seconds. MetricKit uses fixed-width buckets that are device-independent with intervals that are based on the type of metric. Use the [doc://com.apple.metrickit/documentation/MetricKit/MXHistogramBucket/bucketStart] and [doc://com.apple.metrickit/documentation/MetricKit/MXHistogramBucket/bucketEnd] properties to find the start and end of an interval.

The returned results contain only buckets with at least one item so [doc://com.apple.metrickit/documentation/MetricKit/MXHistogram/bucketEnumerator] may not return all intervals.

For example, if the fixed width for the time to resume the app is 10 ms, then the sequence of buckets is:

0…9 ms, 10…19 ms, 20…29 ms, etc.

If there’s data only in the 0…9 ms and 20…29 ms buckets, then the report skips the 10…19 ms bucket.

# MXHistogram

**Class**

An object representing a histogram of data values of the same type of unit.

## Declaration

```swift
class MXHistogram<UnitType> where UnitType : Unit
```

## Overview

A *histogram* measures the number of times a data point for a variable falls into a specific range of possible values within a set of data. Usually, histograms are depicted as bar charts, in which each bar represents a range of values, and the height of each bar represents the number of times the value of the variable falls within a particular range. In this class, each bar is represented by a *bucket*.

A bucket holds the results for a series of measured values, such as all the events occurring between 3 and 5 seconds. MetricKit uses fixed-width buckets that are device-independent with intervals that are based on the type of metric. Use the [doc://com.apple.metrickit/documentation/MetricKit/MXHistogramBucket/bucketStart] and [doc://com.apple.metrickit/documentation/MetricKit/MXHistogramBucket/bucketEnd] properties to find the start and end of an interval.

The returned results contain only buckets with at least one item so [doc://com.apple.metrickit/documentation/MetricKit/MXHistogram/bucketEnumerator] may not return all intervals.

For example, if the fixed width for the time to resume the app is 10 ms, then the sequence of buckets is:

0…9 ms, 10…19 ms, 20…29 ms, etc.

If there’s data only in the 0…9 ms and 20…29 ms buckets, then the report skips the 10…19 ms bucket.

## Reading the buckets

- **bucketEnumerator**: An enumerator for the buckets containing the data in the histogram.
- **totalBucketCount**: The total number of buckets in the histogram.
- **MXHistogramBucket**: An object representing a bucket of data in a histogram.

## Data types

- **MXCallStackTree**: An object representing the call stack for an exception.
- **MXMetaData**: An object containing system-level information about the device.
- **MXAverage**: A unit of measure for an average.
- **MXDiagnostic**: An abstract data class for a diagnostic.
- **MXMetric**: An abstract data class for a metric.
- **MXError.Code**: Error codes for error values from app metrics.
- **MXErrorDomain**: Error domain for error values from app metrics.
- **MXError**: Error domain for error handling of app metrics.
- **MXCrashDiagnosticObjectiveCExceptionReason**: An object that represents the exception reason for an uncaught ObjC exception.
- **MXSignpostRecord**: An object representing the record for a signpost interval or event.

## Inherits From

- NSObject

## Conforms To

- CVarArg
- CustomDebugStringConvertible
- CustomStringConvertible
- Equatable
- Hashable
- NSCoding
- NSObjectProtocol
- NSSecureCoding
